title: Chapter 191
content: # Chapter 191 > **[Mumud's Orb ~ Mumud's Orb]** > > **Rating:** Rare ~ Legendary > > **Rare Rating Information:** > > Durability: 149/149 > > Magic Damage: **+13%** > > Magic Casting Speed: **+5%** > > Number of spells that can be stored: **3** > > * You can permanently store one spell at or below B-grade. > > **Epic Rating Information:** > > Durability: 175/175 > > Magic Damage: **+16%** > > Magic Casting Speed: **+8%** > > Number of spells that can be stored: **3** > > * You can permanently store one spell at or below B-grade. > > **Unique Rating Information:** > > Durability: 200/200 > > Magic Damage: **+20%** > > Magic Casting Speed: **+12%** > > Number of spells that can be stored: **4** > > * You can permanently store one spell at or below A-grade. > > * **10%** reduction in skill cooldown time. > > **Legendary Rating Information:** > > Durability: 247/247 > > Magic Damage: **+27%** > > Magic Casting Speed: **+18%** > > Number of spells that can be stored: **4** > > * You can permanently store one spell at or below S-grade. > > * **15%** reduction in skill cooldown time. > > An orb designed by the dwarven craftsman Milepeu, who taught Pagma before he became a legend. > > The crystal ball made by combining abyss mithril, Frost Queen's Breath, and Water Clan King's Tears allows it to contain enormous power and special functions. > > **User Restriction:** Level 280 or higher. More than 3,000 **Intelligence**. Advanced Orb Mastery Level 5. > > **Weight:** 150 Grid stared at the information window. *A magic possession item?* Storage and possession were different beasts entirely. Stored magic vanished after one use. Possessed magic became part of the item itself, permanent, reusable. Like the Fly magic embedded in Braham's Boots that let non-magicians soar through the air. Magic possession items were efficient beyond measure. Their utility shifted with the spells they held. Millions of users craved them. Dreamed of owning just one. But they were rarer than dragon's teeth. Even veteran players who'd logged in since day one had never laid eyes on such a treasure. Only monster drops from hell-tier bosses, impossible raids, or miracle quests yielded them. In the past, Vantner would've emptied his bank account, sold his house, pawned his soul for Braham's Boots. *This is outside a blacksmith's domain.* Grid was a Legendary blacksmith. He still didn't know how to create magic possession items. His **Legendary Blacksmith's Craftsmanship** sat at level 5, but the section on magic possession items remained empty. A void in his knowledge. Pagma hadn't known either. That much was clear. Yet here Grid stood, production method in hand. The first person among two billion users to learn how to forge a magic possession item. *If I study this orb...* He could crack the secret. Reverse-engineer the principles. The dwarven craftsman Milepeu had taught Pagma once. Now, through this work, Milepeu would teach Grid as well. His knuckles whitened around the Legendary Blacksmith's Hammer. *Thump-thump. Thump-thump.* His pulse hammered in his ears. A grin split his face. Electric anticipation crawled up his spine, flooded his chest. *Through this...* Growth. Evolution. He'd surpass Pagma in this one narrow slice of craftsmanship. And in exchange for this chance to climb higher, he'd bless Euphemina with a Unique rated orb. Grid pulled up the materials list and turned to her. Euphemina handed them over without hesitation. > [22 deluxe magic stones have been acquired.] > [One Frost Queen's Breath has been acquired.] > [One Water Clan King's Tears has been acquired.] > [5 abyss mithril have been acquired.] "I'm asking you." Her voice was steady, but her fingers trembled slightly as she released the materials. Six months of work. Six months of blood, sweat, and near-death experiences to gather these components. The abyss mithril, Frost Queen's Breath, and Water Clan King's Tears were priceless. The magic stones alone ran 4,000 gold each. If Grid burned these materials on an Epic rated result, or worse, Rare... disappointment wouldn't cover it. Euphemina's stomach knotted at the thought. Grid nodded, casual as breathing. "Believe in me." Lauel's face went pale. *We're doomed.* He'd stayed quiet to avoid interfering, but he knew Grid's patterns too well. When Grid said "believe in me," disasters followed. Fires. Explosions. Items that somehow ended up worse than the materials used to make them. "Okay." Euphemina smiled, radiant and trusting. "I'll believe in you." Lauel forced his mouth into something approximating a smile. "Let's leave Grid alone so he can concentrate." "Yes." She beamed at him. Euphemina floated out of the smithy on a cloud of optimism. Lauel's expression curdled the moment she was out of sight. He ground his teeth. *The Unique orb is already gone.* Worst case scenario. Lauel needed Euphemina in the guild. Needed her power, her skills, her potential. If Grid produced a Unique or Legendary orb, Euphemina would pledge herself to Grid on the spot. Loyalty bought with excellence. But the conditions weren't right. Not with Grid's cursed "believe in me" hanging in the air. *If she'd joined us...* Some people played Satisfy like a vacation. Disabled users walked on whole legs. Tourists gawked at vistas Earth couldn't match. Foodies gorged on impossible delicacies. But Satisfy had levels. Wealth gaps. Class systems. Competition was inevitable, baked into the code. Most users didn't treat it like a game. They clawed for every advantage. They leveled frantically. Built power, wealth, reputation. Dreamed of noble titles, of crowns, of armies. The continent's territories, currently held by NPC aristocrats and royalty, would eventually fall into user hands. Natural progression. Lauel intended to ride that wave with Grid at the crest. His master would become a king. To make that happen, he needed talent like Euphemina. Missing this opportunity tasted like ash. Outside, Huroi caught Euphemina before she left. "I really appreciate it. In the past and this time, you saved my life." Euphemina waved him off. "It was Grid, not me, who helped you before. I just helped Grid to clear my own quest. Don't think about the past." She paused. "This time... I couldn't just stand by. It's not something to be thankful for." Deception came naturally to Euphemina when chasing goals. But she wasn't heartless, not toward people she knew. Her weakness and her strength, wrapped in the same package. Color rose in her cheeks as she deflected Huroi's gratitude. Huroi watched her with a quiet smile. She'd saved him from Kasim. Saved his experience points from deletion. He'd repay this debt eventually. Euphemina didn't realize she'd just earned powerful allies. Grid had gained a priceless production method for nothing. Huroi had kept his experience intact. But her attention remained laser-focused on the orb's final rating. *Clang! Clang!* Hammer on metal rang from inside the smithy. Euphemina crept to a small window and peered through. Grid stood before the blast furnace, sweat gleaming on his skin. The firelight painted him in shades of orange and shadow. *He's changed.* The Grid in her memory had been... less. Unremarkable features. A face you'd forget in a crowd. But now he'd grown into his bones. His high nose and pronounced forehead caught the eye. His monolid eyes held a mysterious, Asian charm. Not conventionally handsome, perhaps. But striking. Appealing in unexpected ways. *He didn't get surgery...* The difference was simpler. Hairstyle. Expression. Posture. Before, his hair had flopped messily over his forehead, hiding his better features. His face had been locked in a permanent scowl, lips twisted in complaint. No muscle tone. Shoulders hunched. Back bent like he was carrying the world's weight. Now his hair was neat. His body had filled out with lean muscle. Confidence radiated from his movements, his expressions. The transformation was total. *A miracle.* Warmth spread through her chest. If Grid could change this much, maybe she could too. Maybe someday she'd look back and see growth in herself. Grid's existence grew larger in her mind. A milestone on her path to becoming someone better. --- **Glossary of Common Korean Terms.** **OG:** Glossary Link. **Current schedule:** 20 chapters a week.
